column4: I had fun using a 40MB FAT32 partition on the HD of a laptop, downloading the installer there, and then using a GRUB bootdisk to start the installer.
Then it took some hours to download all the packages from the 'net, but the end result was a working Dapper system (not including the Thinkpad-ish problems I had after that).
Has anyone thought about a world file for Ubuntu?
It means you need, let's say, 10 different programs or packages
They pull in some 200 dependencies
Then you remove one of those programs, but the dependencies that were there only for that program still remain
Is Aptitude a GUI for apt-get?
How do I get to use aptitude?
Thanks, I'll check that
I must admit I had quite a mess with Gentoo's world file too, by manually installing the dependencies too, one at a time.
a "world file"? How do you propose to integrate this into apt?
I don't think it could be integrated.  But it could be an additional functionality for Synaptic, for example.
so how do you propose to integrate it with apt?
A tool in a separate window where you have a) set of all installed packages, b) set of metapackages and c) set of packages not needed by these metapackages and programs.
don't you see that if you integrate it into an apt frontend, you're simply reintroducing what aptitude does?
the functionality needs to be developed at a lower level in the stack than the frontend.
Does aptitude allow one to manually construct the world file, or see the changes it would cause, on a per-package basis?
dpkg already does that, and apt extends it
although your "world file" is fairly ambiguous here.
It is a set of "primary" packages that are wanted for their own functionality, not because something depends on them.
The point is the ability to specify those packages, and see all the unnecessary stale dependencies that are not needed by the specified packages.
please let us migrate to #ubuntu-offtopic, since this is a support channel
No... I think I'll drop my case and see if I can bring this up later somewhere else
fine by me.
